title: How can Darwin's evolutionary theory influence the following fields in economy, agriculture, political science and religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q; How can Darwin’s evolutionary theory influence the following fields in modern times: economy, economy, agriculture, Political Science, religion? A: First of all, Darwin’s theory is a bit old. 160 years or so. It has been supplemented and improved since with understanding of heredity and genes, DNA and the mechanisms involved there, genome mapping and so on. So the question is a bit like asking how steam power has influenced modern railways. That said, the theory of evolution is the basis for modern biology, so everything that has anything to do with biology is affected. Agriculture: A lot in agriculture has been touched by evolution, and since ancient times. The reason that we have wheat and not grass, or why the dessert banana you eat is not green, small, bitter and full of seeds, or why you have broccoli and cauliflower instead of wild mustard, is due to selection. With the understanding of the mechanisms involved in evolution, mapping of genes and gene editing, agricultural scientists can now create entirely new crops, like golden rice (rice plus a gene for beta carotene) or wheat crops that can survive saltier soil. Economy: The effects of the understanding of evolution has not only resulted in agricultural giants in economy, but also medical giants. Both of these are major influences in local and global economy. Trade deals are done around protection of medical intellectual properties and agricultural produce. Religion: Except for a few fundamentalist denominations, mainly parts of the US Evangelical community and the Middle-East Muslim communities, religion has mostly shrugged its shoulder. Those fundamentalists have seriously got their knickers in a twist. Political science: Directly, there’s little influence. Indirectly (se Economy and Religion) the effect is huge. Global economy, and hence global politics, involves those trade deals mentioned. The knowledge base of those sciences and the economical advantages they gain is in conflict with some of the religious base voters in those areas, which in turn has contributed to an ongoing shift in global and economical power to regions that doesn’t have as much fundamentalists in power. The evolution theory, as formulated by Charles Darwin, has been reformulated by genetics and molecular biology, but still the basic functions are1.	the genetic changes –considered as random mutations,2.	adaptive genetic selection – often very accurate, causing efficient fitnessHuman genome is a normal chimaera from functioning metabolism partly from bacteria, body structures from vertebrates, mammals and primates, but thereafter the increase of cortical stem cells started to increase the brain size (Haussler et al 2018: NOTCH2NL, Newly-Identified Human-Specific Genes Influence Brain Size, Chromosome 1). The brains produced another information tool amidst of genes. Evolution with minor genetic differences between primates cannot explain huge functional differences to other primates. Evolution has been needed up to the extent of excellent co-ordination of brain functions a)	with hands and other muscles  producing technologyb)	with throat, mouth and facial muscles  producing tools for communicationc)	with cortical memory and expressions  creativity, consciousness, communication and learning But thereafter these big brain functions have created a basement for an efficient memetic information system. This has liberated humans very much from genetic evolution. People can discover some tools such as eyeglasses, cars or robots, if genetic systems cause difficulties to see, or move or function, but also as an extension of senses and functions. Although the memetic information system is built on the genetic basement, it continues to function very independently and has developed in huge steps into completely new dimensions compared to the genetics. Brains were just a tool to create other more efficient information tools; not only to accumulate information, but to create information tools to accelerate growth and selection of information:•	Doubling of accumulation of complexity in Eukaryote genetic system has taken c400 million years (Sharov & Gordon 2018).•	But human functional complexity has doubled in 20 years (Sharov & Gordon 2018). The number of patents has doubled in the periods of 25 y (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patent)•	Scientific literature has doubled in 15 years 1900 -1960 since 1710 (de Solla Price, 1971).•	The number of integrated circuits doubled every year during 1958-1965 (Moore 1965: ‘Moore’s law’). Similar exponential trends are shown for other technologies as speed of DNA sequencing, hard disc capacity, and bandwidth of networks. The role of information differs from the role of evolution 1)	Information by its definition is meaningful, not random or blind as mutations have thought to be. Meaningless ‘non-information’ is ‘noise’. 2)	Information can liberate humans from slow and disastrous evolution in some extent.3)	The freedom caused by the growing resources of information challenge the human kind to be responsible, to regulate the free will.4)	The free will challenge the role of ideologies and religions to choose between meanings and to target certain long-range meanings.Both evolution (E) and information (I) theory could be applied positive (E+, I+) or negative (E-, I-) way. Better understanding of evolution theory and slow evolution/adaptation of genomes could improve agriculture, economy, and politics. Also many new discoveries and more efficient information systems are necessary to proper management in agriculture, economy, politics and religion, moral responsibility. 1a) Agronomy: A lot of information in human brains and huge economic chains didn’t produce much benefits for domesticated animals or plants, who have suffered in wrong treatments (I-). Better understanding of evolution could improve animal health and happiness and more balanced ecology of cultivation as well as production of organic foods and human health (E+). So information technology could co-operate with understanding of evolution to create a new, happier agriculture (I+, E+).1b) Information technology can lead to genetic manipulation and produce more effective ‘agriculture’ as tissue cultivation without animals or plants, but with the risks of misunderstanding of our own genetic balance (I-, E-?). 2a) Economy: A nation or a company could apply the evolution theory as fighting for survival and by exploiting weaker economies as their resources (E-).2b) The scientific technological progress can be used for the whole human kind for to combat the common problems e.g. poverty, diseases, air/water pollution and for recycling to save resources (I+).3a) Political science could use the evolution theory to rule or even to destroy the weaker units (E-) but also for better understanding of human happiness and to avoid conflicts (E+).3b) Improving information could be use by politics (caretaking of common problems) for to relocate resources and to produce peace, respect of human rights, religious freedom (I+). 4a) Religions could be seen as an evolutionary process from primitive to advanced monotheistic religions and how they would fit for survival (E+), but also as a battle field to destroy others (E-). Evolutionism as a religion or ideology has caused racism, eugenics, and genocide (E-). Some evolutionists rejoice of human disasters as a chance for recovery of nature. Humans have been understood as the worst and most disastrous species without any privilege, which should disappear for saving the nature (E-). Proper information and projects could save many species from extinction (I+).4b) Proper utilization of huge information resources should create common rules for global responsibility (I+). Christians, Muslims, Hindus, Buddhists should agree about responsibility of free will, religious freedom, and human values. Jesus Christ came to teach about love. He died for love and for the salvation of humans. Humans can start from religious repentance to political awakening to global economic responsibility and mutual respect. Strong human rights and Christian love could help caretaking of poor, sick and weaker parts of humanity (I+).

Agriculture is just a subset of biology with a business attached, so evolution affects it at the most basic level. In order to cultivate plants, it helps to know what makes them suited to their environment and what factors could make them more or less productive if you begin to modify them through selective propagation. Early humans began doing this without any concept of evolution, but our modern understanding of the mechanisms behind changes in organisms has enabled much more deliberate and targeted modifications. As for the other fields you mentioned, change in living organisms from one generation to the next won't affect them, as they are abstracts in the human mind, but that mind has been shaped by evolution and the things it does are often explained by the environments in which past humans lived. Hence, it is possible that evolutionary psychology can inform our understanding of those fields. Note that the paragraphs to follow are speculative. For example, compulsive spending despite limited funds may stem from a previous survival advantage conveyed by hoarding food and other supplies at any sign of scarcity. It's not adaptive now, but the brain doesn't know that at the instinctive level, and even looking at numbers that represent things like overdrawn bank accounts may not send a strong enough signal to overcome the instinct. Similarly, our evolutionary past appears to have shaped us to go along with our social group even if we suspect they might be wrong, because being ostracized could be even more dangerous than picking a bad spot to forage or not hunting the best game. When you hear people say they “support XYZ, right or wrong”, that is quite possibly why: at our core, we are social animals and the loyalty of our peers is valued higher than even factual correctness. Obvious examples spring to mind in religion, politics, organizational behavior in business and government, and other fields.

Evolution has been used by many to dismiss even the existence of God. I’m pretty sure that’s an influence on religion. Our Constitution was made only for a moral and religious people. It is wholly inadequate to the government of any other.— John Adams Fewer people believing in and trusting God takes prayer out of Congress and out of schools and replaces it with political corruption and moral decay as is evident in our country and the world today. If life came about by evolution or random chance of any kind, then it’s a wonder that our bodies work, or any living thing, for that matter. If they all came about by happenstance, we could find a way to make them work better and genetic modification of agricultural products could be a boon to man. But, if God brought life into being, if God designed all life and its environments, and if God saw that the life He made was very good, it’s a wonder we get sick, or that anything goes wrong with any life. And any genetic modifications we might make to living things would at least make them worse and possibly be disastrous for us and the whole ecology. Of course, genetic modification, being a new field, would affect the economy slightly. But believing our bodies came about by random chance would affect our medical treatments much more. Perhaps that’s why health care is one sixth of our economy.

In economics, the school of thought most influenced by evolutionary theories in biology is called Evolutionary Economics or Institutional Economics. An early leading writer would be the American economist Thorstein Veblen, and his students went on to create the National Income measures (e.g., GDP) used today and were influential in New Deal policy-making. The late John Kenneth Galbraith would be the most well known modern economist working in the Evolutionary/Institutionalist tradition. See his Affluent Society, for example.

Evolutionary theory can and does impact agriculture in the sense of providing a sound framework for breeding improved varieties of plants and animals. It is completely irrelevant to economics, political science and religion. The so-called “social Darwinism” of Herbert Spencer and his followers in the late 19th and early 20th centuries has been comprehensively discredited, and most evolutionary theorists never thought much of it in the first place. Not on your list are medicine and biology, both of which are largely dependent on an understanding of evolution to advance.
